questions.question:
Question 1: Transport of lipid-soluble substances across the cell membrane occurs via which of the 
following?
questions.explanation:
Lipid-soluble substances are transported across the cell membrane via diffusion. • The rate of diffusion depends directly on lipid solubility. • Characteristics of simple diffusion • The only form of transport that is not carrier-mediated • Occurs down an electrochemical gradient (“downhill”) • Does not require metabolic energy and therefore is passive • Permeability • Describes the ease with which a solute diffuses through a membrane • Depends on the characteristics of the solute and the membrane • Small hydrophobic solutes (e.g., O2) have the highest permeabilities in lipid membranes. • Hydrophilic solutes (e.g., Na+) must cross cell membranes through water-filled channels, or 
pores. If the solute is an ion, then its flux will depend on both the concentration difference and the 
potential difference across the membrane.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following will diffuse more rapidly through phospholipid membranes?
questions.explanation:
Among the following substances, oxygen diffuses more rapidly through phospholipid membranes 
as it is a lipid-soluble substance. Phospholipid membranes are: • Permeable to lipid-soluble substances (e.g., O2, CO2, NH3, steroid hormones) • Impermeable to water-soluble substances (e.g., Na+, Cl-, glucose) • Semipermeable to water

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following is explained by the fick’s law of diffusion?
questions.explanation:
Fick’s law of diffusion explains passive diffusion along the concentration gradient. Fick’s law of diffusion: The magnitude of the diffusing tendency is directly proportional to the 
cross-sectional area across which diffusion is taking place and the concentration gradient, or 
chemical gradient, which is the difference in concentration of the diffusing substance divided by 
the thickness of the membrane. 41 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 4: For a membrane permeable substance, the intracellular concentration (IC) is 10 units and 
extracellular concentration (EC) is 5 units. If the intracellular concentration, surface area of 
the membrane and thickness of the membrane are doubled, and the EC remains the same, 
What will be the net effect on the diffusion? 34 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The net effect on the diffusion is, it becomes 3x. The magnitude of the diffusion: where, • J = net rate of diffusion • D = diffusion coefficient • A = area of the membrane • x = thickness of the membrane or the distance the molecule must travel across for diffusion • c = concentration gradient In the condition mentioned above, the surface area, the thickness of the membrane and 
intracellular concentration becomes doubled. This means, • A is doubled = 2A • x is doubled = 2x • IC is doubled. 10x2= 20 units; EC is 5 units. So, c = 20 - 5 = 15. c was 5 with the original concentrations. Hence c has been tripled. Now, J=-D x 2A x 3c/2x = 3 x [DA c/x] Therefore the diffusion of the substance increases by three-fold. 2nd method : J = - DA (c / x ) After applying changes,c = intracellular conc. - extracellular conc. 
= 10 - 5 
= 5 Therefore, J1 = - DA (5 / x ) After appropriate doublings, 
New intracellular conc. = 10 * 2 = 20 
New extracellular conc. = 
5 (since no change) 
c = 20 - 5 = 15 Therefore, J2 = - D 2*A (15 / 2*x ) = - D A (15 / x ) Now, 
J2 / J1 = [- DA (15 / x ) ] / [ = - DA (5 / x ) ] J2 / J1 = 15 / 5 = 3 Therefore the diffusion of the substance increases by three-fold.

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following does not follow transport saturation kinetics?
questions.explanation:
42 
Sold by @itachibot Simple diffusion is not carrier-mediated transport hence do not follow saturation kinetics. • Facilitated diffusion, primary active transport, and secondary active transport all involve integral 
membrane proteins and are called carrier-mediated transport. • All carrier-mediated transport system follows saturation kinetics. • The figure shows that as the concentration of the diffusing substance increases, the rate of 
simple diffusion continues to increase proportionately, but in the case of facilitated diffusion, the 
rate of diffusion cannot rise greater than the transport maximum (Tm). Tm is analogous to 
the maximum velocity (Vmax) level in enzyme kinetics.

questions.question: Question 6: Which statement about the facilitated diffusion is true?
questions.explanation:
When carrier proteins help in the movement of substances in the direction of their chemical or 
electrical gradients (downhill movement), no energy input is required and the process is called 
facilitated diffusion. Examples • GLUT • Urea Transporters : • UTA 1, 2, 3, 4 in Kidney • UTB in RBC • Amino Acid Transporters Other options are wrong because: • Facilitated diffusion is a type of passive transport. • It follows saturation kinetics. • No energy input is required in facilitated diffusion. 43 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 7: The movement of which of the following substance across the membrane is most affected by 
osmotic pressure?
questions.explanation:
The movement of water across the membrane is most affected by osmotic pressure. Osmotic pressure is the pressure that would have to be applied to prevent the movement of water 
molecules to the more concentrated solution i.e. to a region in which there is higher concentration 
of a solute to which the membrane is impermeable. • Osmotic pressure is calculated by Vant Hoff’s law.

questions.question:
Question 8: Osmolarity is defined as 35 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
44 
Sold by @itachibot Difference between osmolarity & osmolality: • Osmolarity is the number of osmoles per litre of solution, • Osmolality is the number of osmoles per kilogram of solvent. • Therefore, osmolarity is affected by the volume of the various solutes in the solution and the 
temperature, while the osmolality is not.

questions.question: Question 9: Passive transfer of only solvent occurs in
questions.explanation:
Passive transfer of the only solvent occurs in Osmosis. The diffusion of solvent molecules into a region in which there is a higher concentration of a 
solute to which the membrane is impermeable is called osmosis. Note: Membrane is impermeable to the solute.

questions.question:
Question 10: A 47-year-old diabetic man takes a low-dose aspirin daily due to cardiovascular risk. The 
absorption of aspirin in the stomach is an example of which type of transport?
questions.explanation:
The absorption of salicylates like aspirin in the stomach is an example of nonionic diffusion. • Some weak acids and bases are quite soluble in cell membranes in the undissociated form, but 
they cannot cross membranes in the charged (i.e. dissociated) form. Consequently, molecules of 
the undissociated substance diffuse from one side of the membrane to the other and then 
dissociate. This phenomenon is called nonionic diffusion. Examples • Ammonia excretion in collecting ducts • Excretion of weak acids and bases in the kidney • Absorption of salicylates in the stomach • Absorption of bile acids in the distal ileum

questions.question: Question 11: Energy is required in which of the following mode of transport.
questions.explanation:
When a carrier protein transports substances against their electrical and chemical gradients 
(uphill movement) it requires energy and this type of transport is called active transport. 45 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 12: Movement of calcium from the cytosol to the extracellular space takes place by 36 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The movement of calcium from the cytosol to the extracellular space takes place by primary active 
transport. Two primary active transport calcium pumps maintain low intracellular calcium levels. One 
pumps calcium ions to the extracellular space and another to the sarcoplasmic reticulum. Calcium transport also takes place via secondary active transport. A sodium-calcium 
exchanger/antiporter moves sodium ions to the interior and calcium ions to the exterior.

questions.question: Question 13: Na+-K+ ATP pump uses
questions.explanation:
Na+- K+ ATPase or Na+-K+ ATP pump catalyzes the hydrolysis of ATP to ADP and uses the 
energy to extrude three Na+ from the cell and take two K+ into the cell for each molecule of ATP 
hydrolyzed. Sodium-Potassium Pump/ Na+– K+ Pump: • Carrier protein located on the plasma membrane of all cells • Pumps 3 Na+ out of the cell & 2 K+ into the cell (coupling ratio 3:2) • 2 separate globular proteins: • Larger-  subunit & smaller-  subunit,  subunit concerned with Na+- K+ transport • Binding sites on  subunit: • 3 intracellular sites- for Na+, ATP, and one phosphorylation site • 2 extracellular sites- for K+ and oubain 46 
Sold by @itachibot Mechanism Of Action Functions: • Controlling Cell Volume. • Electrogenic Nature- maintains Resting membrane potential • The energy from the Na+–K+ pump also indirectly serves as the energy source for secondary 
active transport. Regulation: • Pump activity is altered by second messenger molecules eg. cAMP, DAG • Stimulated by thyroid hormones, insulin and aldosterone • Inhibition by dopamine ,digitalis glycosides, ouabain 47 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 14: Primary active transport is mediated by which one of the following enzymes?
questions.explanation:
In active transport the energy is provided almost exclusively by the hydrolysis of ATP. Hence 
many carrier molecules are ATPases (eg. Na+-K+-ATPase), enzymes that catalyze the hydrolysis of 
ATP. PRIMARY ACTIVE TRANSP 
ORT SECONDARY ACTIVE TRAN 
SPORT Requiresdirect input of meta 
bolic energyin the form of ad 
enosine triphosphate(ATP) The transport of two or more 
solutes is coupled and metab 
olic energy is providedindirec 
tlyfrom the Na+gradient that 
is maintained across cell me 
mbranes by Na+-K+-ATPase 
pump a) Na+- glucose cotransportb) a) Na+-K+-ATPase or sodium

Pasec) H+-ATPase or proton

H+-K+-ATPase Na+-Ca2+counter transport

questions.question: Question 15: For Na+-K+ ATPase coupling ratio is
questions.explanation:
Na+-K+ ATPase or Na+-K+ ATP pump is an electrogenic pump in that it moves three positive 
charges out of the cell for each two that it moves in, and it is therefore said to have a coupling 
ratio of 3:2. Note: • Na+-K+ ATP pump is found in almost all parts of the body, and it catalyzes the hydrolysis of ATP 
to ADP and uses the energy for its activity • It is one of the ma˜or energy using process in the body. On an average, it accounts for 24% of the 
energy utilized by the cells, and in neurons it accounts for 70%. Thus, it accounts for large share 
in basal metabolism

questions.question:
Question 16: A 40-year-old diabetic man has been prescribed empagliflozin. Which of the following 
processes will most likely be affected by this drug? 37 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Empagliflozin is an SGLT-2 inhibitor. SGLT-2 or sodium-glucose transport protein 2 is an 
example of a cotransporter that plays a key role in glucose absorption from renal tubule 
by secondary active transport. This process is blocked by SGLT-2 inhibitors, leading to renal loss 
of glucose and improved glycemic control. • A special property of the transport protein involved in secondary active transport is that a 
conformational change to allow Na+ movement to the interior will not occur until a glucose 48 
Sold by @itachibot molecule also attaches to the transport protein. When they both become attached, the 
conformational change takes place automatically, and the Na+ and glucose are transported to the 
inside of the cell at the same time. • The figure shows glucose is transported uphill and Na+ is transported downhill. Energy derived 
from the downhill movement of Na+ is maintained by the Na+-K+ ATPase pump on the 
basolateral side.

questions.question: Question 17: Glucose is absorbed in intestine by?
questions.explanation:
Glucose is absorbed in the intestine by secondary active transport (sodium co-transport). The energy for glucose transport is provided indirectly, by the active transport of Na+ out of the 
cell. This maintains the concentration gradient across the luminal border of the cell so that more 
Na+ and consequently more glucose enter. Though both secondary active transport and facilitated diffusion play a role in glucose absorption, 
it is the initial active transport of sodium through the basolateral membranes of the intestinal 
epithelial cells that provide the eventual force for moving glucose through the membranes as well. 
So, secondary active transport is the single best answer for this question.

questions.question:
Question 18: A 40-year-old lady is diagnosed with Lambart- Eaton syndrome. Radioimmunoassay reveals 
the presence of serum antibodies against voltage-gated calcium channels. Which of the 
following process will be affected as a result of this pathology?
questions.explanation:
Exocytosis of neurotransmitters at the nerve terminals will be affected as a result of antibodies 
against voltage-gated calcium channels. After an action potential reaches the terminal endings of a nerve, the influx of Ca2+ via 
voltage-gated calcium channels leads to the fusion of intracellular vesicles with cell membranes. 
This results in the release of neurotransmitters into the synaptic space. This process will be 
impaired in the case of Lambert-eaton syndrome. 49 
Sold by @itachibot Exocytosis is the extrusion of membrane-bound vesicles. In exocytosis, intracellular vesicles move 
to the cell membrane, fuse with it and then release their contents to the extracellular fluid. Solute 
and water can be released from the cell via vesicles by the process of exocytosis. Exocytosis can be: Constitutive exocytosis: • Involves prompt transport of proteins to the cell membrane in vesicles, with little or no 
processing or storage • Examples • Goblet cells in the intestine continuously to release mucus • Fibroblasts in connective tissue release collagen Regulated/ Non constitutive exocytosis: • Here the proteins from golgi apparatus initially enter the secretory granules, where the 
processing of prohormones to mature hormones occurs before exocytosis • Examples • Endocrine cells, hormones are stored in secretory vesicles and released in response to a signal 
from outside the cell. • To insert proteins into the cell membrane like aquaporin insertion Note: • The term ‘regulated exocytosis’ is misleading because even constitutive exocytosis is regulated. • Exocytosis involves two families of proteins: Rabs, which help vesicles dock onto the membrane, 
and SNAREs, which facilitate membrane fusion. • This is Ca2+ -dependent process • Exocytosis, like endocytosis, requires energy in the form of ATP. 50 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 19: Which pathway is called regulated pathway?
questions.explanation:
The non constitutive pathway of exocytosis is called the regulated pathway. Exocytosis can be either constitutive or non constitutive(regulated): • Regulated or nonconstitutive pathway: Proteins from the Golgi apparatus initially enter 
secretory granules, where processing of prohormones to the mature hormones occurs before 
exocytosis. • Constitutive pathway: Involves the prompt transport of proteins to the cell membrane in 
vesicles, with little or no processing or storage.

questions.question:
Question 20: 38 
Sold by @itachibot A 30-year-old gentleman is diagnosed with elevated blood cholesterol levels. A defect in a 
process that involves the protein 'clathrin' is being suspected. Which of the following process 
will be most likely affected by this defect?
questions.explanation:
Receptor-mediated endocytosis takes place in coated pits or indentations where the cytoplasmic 
side of the membrane has high concentrations of protein. The most common protein found in 
coated pits is clathrin. A GTP binding protein dynamin is involved in pinching off the vesicle formed in 
clathrin-mediated endocytosis Importance: • Internalisation of many receptors and ligands bound to them eg. LDL, Nerve Growth Factor. • Receptor-mediated endocytosis transports a variety of substances including protein hormones, 
growth factors, antibodies, and plasma proteins that serve as carriers for iron and cholesterol. • Synaptic function • Abnormalities in receptor-mediated removal of cholesterol from the blood are associated with 
elevated plasma cholesterol levels and cardiovascular disease. 51 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 21: Which of the following is true about secretory vesicle transport?
questions.explanation:
Vesicular transport has no relation to the concentration gradient. Vesicular transport requires energy expenditure by the cell, so this is an active method of 
membrane transport. Energy is needed to accomplish vesicle formation and vesicle movement 
within the cell. METHOD OF TRA

gh the cell intact.

questions.question: Question 22: Transcytosis occurs in which of the following cell types?
questions.explanation:
Transcytosis is seen in epithelial cells of intestine. Transcytosis is endocytosis across one 
membrane of the cell followed by exocytosis across the opposite membrane. Transcytosis across epithelia or endothelia: Some molecules, such as proteins, are too large to 
diffuse through the membrane or cross the membrane transporters of epithelia. Instead they are 
moved across epithelia by transcytosis. Steps: • The molecule is brought into the epithelial cell via receptor-mediated endocytosis. 52 
Sold by @itachibot • The resulting vesicle attaches to microtubules in the cells cytoskeleton and is transported across 
the cell by vesicular transport. • At the opposite side of the epithelium, the contents of the vesicle are expelled into the interstitial 
fluid by exocytosis. Significance: • Transcytosis makes it possible for large proteins to move across an epithelium and remain 
intact. • It is the means by which infants absorb maternal antibodies in breast milk. The antibodies are 
absorbed on the apical surface of the infant’s intestinal epithelium and then released into the 
extracellular fluid.

questions.question: Question 23: Which of the following ion is used in exocytosis?
questions.explanation:
As exocytosis, begins  in intracellular Ca2+  Ca2+interacts with a calcium sensing protein  
secretory vesicle docking and fusion  fused area of membrane opens, the vesicle contents diffuse 
into the extracellular fluid while the vesicle membrane stays behind and becomes part of the cell 
membrane.

questions.question:
Question 24: 39 
Sold by @itachibot A 35-year-old diabetic man is started on an insulin secretagogue. Which of the following ions 
is required for emeiocytosis or reverse pinocytosis during the insulin secretion process?

options.b: Effect of one permeant ion on the distribution of other permeant ions
options.c: Effect of a permeant ion on the distribution of nondiffusible ions
options.d: Effect of a non-diffusible ion on the distribution of permeant ions

questions.explanation:
Emeiocytosis requires Ca2+ directly. Emeiocytosis is the movement of secretory granules to the plasma membrane of the cell, fusion of 
the granule surface membrane with the cell membrane, rupture of membranes, and liberation of 
granular contents into the pericapillary space. Insulin secretion (as shown in the image below): 53 
Sold by @itachibot • Glucose enters B cells by GLUT-2 transporters. • It is phosphorylated and metabolized to pyruvate (Pyr) in the cytoplasm. • The Pyr enters the mitochondria and is metabolized via the citric acid cycle. The ATP formed by 
oxidative phosphorylation inhibits ATP-sensitive K+ channels, reducing K+ efflux. • This depolarizes the B cell, and Ca2+ influx is increased. The Ca2+ stimulates the release of 
insulin by exocytosis. Glutamate (Glu) is also formed, and this primes secretory granules, 
preparing them for exocytosis. It is promoted by Ca2+,  K+ It is inhibited by Mg2+, K+ depletion. The process of emeiocytosis for insulin secretion is depicted in the image below. 54 
Sold by @itachibot Membrane Potentials
